Award.AwardTitle: Computational and Experimental Multiscale Analysis of Heterogeneous Solids and Metamaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to investigate the application of multiscale analysis for wave propagation in solids with heterogeneities and microstructured materials. A novel analysis technique to account for the multiple scales that appear at the level of the geometric discretization of the analysis domain is proposed. This method relies on the formulation of multi-node elements, called multiscale elements, capable of explicitly modeling the actual geometry of the material at sub-elemental length scales. Within each element, geometric and material heterogeneities are incorporated through locally tailored multiscale interpolation functions. These shape functions approximate the unknown displacement and stress fields from a finite number of nodal values and are obtained as local solutions of the differential operator governing the problem at the small scales. The developed methodology will be applied to the design of periodic and graded metamaterials for wave guiding, steering and focusing applications.

Research findings will improve the understanding of wave motion in damaged structures, and will enable the detailed characterization and quantification of structural damage in critical structural components. Advances from the research topics will be disseminated widely through academic courses on wave mechanics and in undergraduate research opportunities. Broadening of participation will be achieved by specifically working with underrepresented students in conjunction with ongoing programs available at Georgia Tech. In addition, educational laboratory activities and classroom modules, developed through the GIFT program at Georgia Tech, will expose high school and middle school underrepresented students to basic results of the research and to underlying wave mechanics principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the application of multiscale analysis for wave propagation in solids with heterogeneities, and microstructured materials. We developed a multiscale simulation capability for the efficient computation of the dynamic behavior of solids with microstructures and flaws, and its experimental validation and characterization through detailed mapping of the wave-fields. The developed technique, termed as Geometric Multi Scale Finite Element Method (G-MsFEM), accounts for multiplicity of scales appearing at the level of the geometric discretization of the domain of analysis. The method relies on the formulation of multi-node elements, called multiscale elements (MsE), capable of explicitly modeling the actual geometry of the material at sub-elemental length scales. Within each MsE, geometric and material heterogeneities, such as voids, cracks or inclusions, are incorporated through locally tailored multiscale interpolation functions. This approach advances the state-of-the-art in multiscale Finite Elements by allowing the study of structural/material configurations with multiscale features occurring at the geometrical level such as voids, cracks and inclusions, and by retaining all the element degrees of freedom (DoFs), which are assembled as part of the global FE model so that all small scales and large scale features are simultaneously resolved. Moreover, the developed procedures require minimal end-user intervention and are well suited to be implemented in commercial FE software packages. For problems of application considered during this project, the G-MsFEM method showed to capture the relevant physics while requiring a relatively low computational cost.

The impact of this research is potentially very broad. The method could facilitate scientific understanding in the general areas of acoustic metamaterials, structural health monitoring and non-destructive evaluation. The developed methodologies could be applied, for example, to the development of high-frequency signal processing devices used in communication systems (mobile phones, GPS units, etc.), for noise & vibration control, and for ultrasound medical devices. In addition, our study improves the understanding of wave motion in damaged structures, and enable the detailed characterization and quantification of structural damage in critical structural components.

In addition to conducting research activities, the PI performed extensive outreach and mentoring activities within the context of this project. The PI implemented a special mentoring program with a freshman student of Hispanic origin and a sophomore African-American female student. Students were assigned advanced reading materials on strength of materials (which they have not taken as a class at this point in their studies) and met weekly with the PI to discuss the material and solve problems of application. Finally, the PI performed outreach activities for teachers and Latino students in the Atlanta Metropolitan Area. Activities included, among others, hands-on activities on structural design for students, and participation in parent-oriented panels related to pursuing academic studies in STEM fields.
